text: hi everyone
Anthony Fantana here the Internet's
busiest music nerd and it's time for a
review of the new darkthrone LP the
underground resistance darkthrone is a
metal duo who has had one of the most
interesting trajectories of any group to
really kind of come out of the Norwegian
black metal scene in the 90s darkthrone
was responsible for penning a few of
black metals true classics and then
later after that they progressed a
little bit into death metal which they
dabbled in for a very short period of
time but then in the 2000s they
eventually found the beauty in
old-school heavy metal and crust punk
combining those with their black metal
sound for some pretty interesting full
lengths which are decent metal releases
but the people who wanted them to stick
to their true blood black metal sound
were understandably disappointed now not
only did arc throw and bring to their
music a change in musical style but it
was kind of a change in character -
because albums such as circle the wagons
and dark Thrones and black flags are
nowhere near as brooding there's not
this pervasive sense of Darkness and
demonic feelings or occult nests instead
these more recent dark throne releases
feel like testosterone fueled chest
beating with vocals that reference the
old school of metal but are maybe like a
little kind of cartoony a little over
the top and their guitar riffs and their
drumbeats and their solos reference this
era of metal - taking ideas from artists
like Iron Maiden and Judas Priest and
Motorhead as well as merciful fate and
the underground resistance is yet
another sequel in this saga but this
time it's personal
not really I just wanted to say that the
band is actually sounding more
old-school metal than ever on on this LP
with their crust punk and their black
metal influences kind of dissipating on
these six tracks the introduction to the
track dead early is old-school as hell
it sounds like a combination of ac/dc
and Motorhead with this bass drum and
bass guitar kind of stomping a
over and over and over on top of the
speedy guitar riff and once the song
gets going the vocals just croak I mean
in this way that's kind of funny I know
that the band must be conscious of what
great metal vocals are I mean they've
been in the metal scene for so frickin
long and have had great fantastic black
metal vocals on their earliest releases
however I can't help but feel like the
vocals they've been putting on their
most recent releases especially this one
are kind of satirical and in this
specific case maybe a little bit of a
mockery of the old school maybe not in a
way where they're trying to directly
insult and piss some people off but it
doesn't really feel like dark throat is
that into taking themselves too
seriously which if your dark throne
might be something they're kind of sick
of at this point considering the very
very serious black metal scene that
they've been surrounded by for most of
their musical career so the underground
resistance is is definitely an LP that
if you're gonna enjoy it requires an
extra helping of context not only do you
need to be familiar with what dark
throne used to do musically but I feel
like you need to also be aware of what
old-school metal stereotypes are so you
could kind of see and hear what exactly
dark throne is playing off of taking
inspiration from and ever-so-slightly
parodying as far as the guitar riffs on
this LP go throughout they are pretty
predictable and familiar but solid and
very well performed against the drums
the guitar and the drums hit some pretty
awesome metal grooves on one track after
another the song dead early right at the
start of this thing is very head bang
worthy and the song Valkyrie is like a
beautiful awesomely written metal ballad
it feels snowy and the way the song
paces along it feels like a trudge in
foot deep snow it is epic there's some
great guitar melodies on this one a bit
of acoustic guitar at the intro and then
after this track the band basically
hammers out one heavy metal riff after
another
until they basically reach the 13 minute
closing track leave no cross unturned
which is a bit of speed metal worship
that has this King Diamond like
introduction leave no crosses and all of
the really bad cartoony vocals from the
past five tracks all kind of show up for
this one group appearance
sometimes singing all at once sometimes
trading places throughout the track the
band really yucks it up and I mean they
have to be completely conscious of how
bad the vocals sounds sometimes that
falsetto that I just impersonate it a
second ago that part on the song
actually feels like it was a splice of
two different vocal takes or something
because they don't really transition in
a way that feels smooth or even humanly
possible and there are other very very
audible vocal flubs all over this LP I
mean the melodic vocals on Valkyrie are
really flat and the song the ones you
left behind the vocal harmonies the male
vocal harmonies all over that track they
are messy as hell
I mean sloppy Slaven Lee the band seems
to put so much effort into crafting some
of these 4-minute songs with a lot of
different riffs and segues and in parts
and some great solos however the vocals
are so terrible the closer is especially
where things get kind of confusing
because some of the worst vocal parts on
this entire LP are there and yet it was
no small undertaking for the band to
craft this 13-minute monster that when
it comes to the drums and the guitars is
actually pretty engaging throughout the
entire thing I mean it feels like they
really wanted to pull off an authentic
speed metal track with an antenna
character to it for me the vocals on
this LP are either the way they are
because of two different things either
Darkthrone doesn't give a [ __ ] about how
they sound or they're intentionally bad
in either way that's only going to
attract a certain kind of metal listener
overall in this LP the riffs are pretty
good they're dusty but they're performed
well the production is is pretty decent
and stays true to that old-school metal
sound but the cartoony vibes that I'm
getting from the vocals are just
too distracting when it comes to being
kind of silly with your vocals
I feel like at this point dark thorn has
surpassed even a band like ghoul I do
love that darkthrone wanted to put a fun
metal album together I mean I do love
fun metal music that's why I like thrash
metal so much and the vocals on
underground resistance definitely do
give the band character where if they
maybe played the vocals as straight as
they do the drums and the guitars it
might have just been a boring
nondescript record that really kind of
had nothing to report and this weird
sort of funny crazy character does make
the album fun for most of the tracks but
by the time I get to the last song on
here the 13 minute closer which is one
of my favorite tracks on here it gets
kind of old honestly I'm feeling a
strong 5 to a light 6 on this thing if
you've given it a listen what did you
think did you love it did you hate it
why what do you think I should review
next and have a nice day Anthony Fantana
Darkthrone forever
[Music]
you
